## <span style="display: block; text-align: center; font-size: 0.95em;">Why Bioinformatics for Cancer Control Research?</span>

<div style="font-size:0.85em; line-height:1.5;">
<strong>Cutting edge cancer control research requires:</strong>
<ul>
  <li><strong>Molecular characterization</strong> of disparities across populations</li>
  <li><strong>Ancestry analysis</strong> to understand genetic contributions to risk</li>
  <li><strong>Biomarker discovery</strong> for prevention and early detection</li>
  <li><strong>Intervention response</strong> measurement at molecular level</li>
  <li><strong>Integration</strong> of genomic, environmental, and behavioral data</li>
</ul>
</div>

::: {.notes}
CCPS research increasingly uses molecular data to understand disparities, identify who's at risk, and measure intervention effectiveness. This requires specialized bioinformatics expertise to design studies, analyze complex data, and translate findings into actionable insights.
:::

### <span style="display: block; text-align: center;">Strengthening Your Grant Applications</span>

:::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="42%"}
![](slide_figures/DMSP-plan.png){width=92%}
<div style="margin-top:0.6em; font-size:0.9em; line-height:1.3;">
<strong>NIH expects plans for:</strong><br>
• Code & software<br>
• Data management & sharing<br>
• Computational resources
</div>
:::
::: {.column width="58%"}
<div style="font-size:0.9em; line-height:1.4;">
**If your project includes high-dimensional data, an expert bioinformatician makes the proposal stronger.**
</div>
<div style="margin-top:0.6em; font-size:0.75em; line-height:1.4;">
  <ul class="checklist">
    <li>Assays chosen with clear rationale</li>
    <li>Experimental design avoids QC pitfalls</li>
    <li>Named personnel to analyze data</li>
    <li>Code &amp; software packages specified</li>
    <li>Compute &amp; storage resources identified</li>
    <li>Results visualization approach defined</li>
  </ul>
</div>
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
We help craft compelling data management plans, justify analytical approaches, and budget appropriately. This is especially critical for studies involving diverse populations, longitudinal designs, or multi-omics approaches.
:::

---

### <span style="display: block; text-align: center;">Experience = Robust, Reproducible Analyses</span>

:::: {.columns style="display: flex; align-items: center;"}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](slide_figures/batch-effect.png){width=100%}
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
<div style="font-size:0.85em; line-height:1.4;">
<strong>Critical for cancer control research:</strong>
<ul>
  <li>Distinguishing technical artifacts from biological signal</li>
  <li>Batch effects in longitudinal studies</li>
  <li>Small sample sizes from diverse populations</li>
  <li>Complex experimental designs (interventions, time series)</li>
</ul>
</div>
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
Our experience with hundreds of datasets means we catch problems early. This is especially important for intervention studies where batch effects could mask real treatment effects, or population studies where technical variation could be confused with biological differences between groups.
:::
